questions.text: A mother observed unusual redness on the palms of her young child while putting him to sleep. She brings him to your OPD and on examination, you find mild abdominal distension, splenomegaly, and pedal edema. You admit the child for further evaluation, but on the night of admission, he suddenly starts vomiting fresh blood. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A child presenting with hematemesis and splenomegaly is presumed to have variceal bleeding unless proved otherwise. Bleeding from oesophagal varices is the most common presentation of portal hypertension.

Palmar erythema(redness of the palms) and ascites (swelling of the abdomen) are features of liver failure seen in this patient. 

Upper GI endoscopy is the preferred diagnostic test for oesophagal varices. 

The management of acute variceal bleeding-

  • Attain hemodynamic stability through blood transfusion/fluids
  • Vasoactive drugs (e.g., octreotide)
  • Endoscopy to perform ligation or sclerotherapy
  • Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt should be considered for variceal bleeding refractory to medical and endoscopic therapy.     

Secondary prophylaxis to reduce the recurrence of bleeding includes-

  • Nonselective β blockade (propranolol, nadolol)
  • Obliteration of varices through serial treatment via ligation or sclerotherapy

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was brought by his mother to the ER after having a sudden episode of vomiting blood. On examination, splenomegaly is detected with engorged superficial veins around his umbilicus. Which is the investigation of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
A child presenting with hematemesis and splenomegaly is presumed to have variceal bleeding and hence, upper GI endoscopy is the investigation of choice.

The upper GI endoscopy provides a definitive diagnosis and an option to treat via band ligation or sclerotherapy. 

Capsule endoscopy, ultrasound, CT, MRI, and elastography are not recommended because of their suboptimal accuracy compared to endoscopy. Capsule endoscopy is used to investigate an occult/obscure gastrointestinal bleed mostly suspected to be in the small intestine.

questions.text: Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which did not subside even after 3 weeks of birth, was observed in a neonate. On investigating, liver enzymes, PT/INR and albumin levels were normal. No hemolysis was seen on a peripheral blood smear. A drop in bilirubin level was observed within a week after treating with phenobarbital. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Jaundice persisiting 3 weeks after birth is suggestive of pathological jaundice. Among the given options, Crigler Najjar type 2 presents with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia which responds to phenobarbital therapy.  

Dubin Johnson (option C) and Rotor (option A) syndromes lead to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. 

Crigler Najjar type 2 is an autosomal recessive disease with non-hemolytic, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia caused by homozygous missense mutations in the enzyme UDP UGT1A1 resulting in reduced (partial) enzymatic activity.

The differences between Crigler-Najjar type 1 and type 2 are described in the table below:

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy was brought to the OPD by his father who observed a yellowish tinge to his skin and eyes. He gives a history of recent onset fatigue after playing football for a few minutes and cannot stay active on the playground for a long time like before. Investigations revealed isolated conjugated hyperbilirubinemia but are normal otherwise. Liver histology revealed a black pigment. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of fatigue, conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and black pigment on liver biopsy, termed as "black liver" is suggestive of Dubin–Johnson syndrome.

Dubin-Johnson syndrome is an autosomal recessive inherited defect in hepatocyte secretion of bilirubin glucuronide. Disease results from absent function of multiple drug-resistant protein 2, an ATP dependent canalicular transporter.

The most commonly reported symptoms are abdominal pain and fatigue, jaundice, dark urine, and slight enlargement of the liver.

Inherited conjugated hyperbilirubinemia-

Dubin–Johnson syndrome Rotor syndrome
Autosomal recessive Autosomal recessive
Absent function of multiple drug-resistant protein (MRP-2) Defect in anion transport
Black liver on biopsy (due to accumulation of epinephrine metabolite) Black liver is not seen
Normal levels of coproporphyrin in urine Increased levels of coproporphyrin in urine 
Gall bladder is not visualized on oral cholecystography Gall bladder is visualized on oral cholecystography

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the paediatrics department and a child with Dubin-Johnson syndrome is admitted to your unit. During rounds, the attending paediatrician asks you which molecular defect causes liver disease in this patient. Your answer would be
questions.solution:
Molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin–Johnson syndrome is ABCC2 (codes for canalicular protein with ATP-binding cassette), it leads to the mutation of multiple drug-resistant protein 2 (MRP2) receptor. Hence, there is a defect in the transfer of conjugated bilirubin from the liver to bile in Dubin–Johnson syndrome.

Important diseases and their molecular defects:

ATP7B  Wilson disease 
CFTR  Cystic fibrosis 
SERPINA 1  α-1 antitrypsin deficiency

questions.text: All are true about transient familial neonatal hyperbilirubinemia, except:

choices.text: Occurs due to maternal antibody against fetal UGT1A1
It is also known as Lucey Driscoll syndrome
Stop breast feeding when jaundice sets in

questions.solution:
Lucey Driscoll syndrome or transient familial neonatal hyperbilirubinemia is a self-limiting condition and there is no need to stop breastfeeding.

Lucey Driscoll syndrome is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder affecting enzymes involved in bilirubin metabolism. It causes transient familial neonatal unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and jaundice occurs during the first 4 days of life. It is due to maternal antibodies against fetal UGT1A1 (UDP glucuronosyltransferase family 1 member A1).

questions.text: Lately, a teacher observed that an anxious young girl had started drooling saliva from her mouth while listening in the classroom. She had also developed a deterioration in her handwriting while taking down notes. Her mother was informed and she brought her child to your clinic. On examination, she had tremors and mild hepatomegaly. A slit-lamp examination was done and showed the following picture. The right statement about this disease is -

choices.text: Coombs-positive hemolytic anaemia may be present.
Patient can be treated with triethylenetetramine

questions.solution:
The image shows the Kayser-Fleischer ring, which is characteristic of Wilson's disease. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, characterised by low serum ceruloplasmin levels. Coomb's negative hemolytic anemia may be present. The patient can be treated with triethylenetetramine also known as trientine.

Wilson’s disease is caused due to a loss-of-function mutation in the ATP7B gene on Chr.13q. The gene encodes a copper transporting ATPase (ATP7B) which has 2 functions:

  • Maintains copper in bound form by binding copper to apoceruloplasmin
  • Helps excrete free copper in bile.

Thus, an ATP7B deficiency leads to excess deposition of free copper within tissues.

Lab markers Change in Wilson's disease Reason
Serum ceruloplasmin ↓↓ ATP7B deficiency results in reduced bound copper
24h urinary copper ↑↑ Excess free copper excreted in urine
Total serum copper ↓ Due to marked reduction in ceruloplasmin

The drugs used in the management of Wilson's disease include:

  • Chelating agents as first-line drugs
    • D-penicillamine
    • Trientine or triethylenetetramine
  • Elemental zinc as maintenance therapy.

questions.text: In Wilson Disease, hepatic copper content usually exceeds____ Œºg/g dry weight.
questions.solution:
In Wilson disease, hepatic copper content usually exceeds 250 μg/g dry weight.

Hepatic copper accumulation is the hallmark of Wilson disease. It is measured using neutron activation analysis/atomic absorption spectrometry.

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy was brought to the OPD by his mother with a history of fatigue and myalgia for a few days, associated with rashes that started a week before it. On examination, coppery-red coloured skin lesions were seen on the face and limbs including palms and soles. His serology was positive for HBsAg. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The coppery-red colored papules along with a positive HBsAg are suggestive of Gianotti-Crosti syndrome, also known as papular acrodermatitis.

It is an immunologic reaction to viral infections. The most common associations are Epstein-Barr virus, hepatitis B virus, Coxsackievirus A16, and parainfluenza virus, as well as with many childhood immunizations.

Skin lesions are monomorphic, firm, coppery red papules sized 1-10 mm. They occur in crops and may become profuse and coalesce into plaques, forming a symmetric eruption on the face, ears, buttocks, and limbs, including the palms and soles. The trunk, scalp, and mucous membrane are relatively spared.

The image given below shows the coppery red papules seen in Gianotti-Crosti syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs are not used in the treatment of hepatitis B?
questions.solution:
Ribavirin is a drug used in the treatment of hepatitis C,¬†not hepatitis B.

Indications for starting antiviral therapy in chronic hepatitis B are:

  • Patients without cirrhosis
    • HBeAg + with HBV DNA >20,000 IU/mL and ALT level >2 times the upper limit of normal
    • HBeAg -ve with HBV DNA >2000 IU/mL and ALT level >2 times the upper limit of normal
  • Patients with compensated cirrhosis and an HBV DNA >2000 IU/mL
  • Patients developing acute liver failure or decompensated cirrhosis.

Drugs used in the treatment of hepatitis B are:

  • First-line treatment: Entecavir or tenofovir¬†
  • Other drugs:
    • Pegylated interferon-alpha¬†
    • Telbivudine
    • Lamivudine
    • Adefovir

questions.text: A young child developed sudden bouts of vomiting and was brought to the ER.  Her condition rapidly worsened as she developed seizures. She had a history of influenza infection one week ago. The patient's liver biopsy will show ______.
questions.solution:
Severe vomiting in a 5-year-old child, rapidly worsening to seizures, with a history of viral infection (influenza) is suggestive of Reye's syndrome. Hence, liver biopsy will show marked microvesicular steatosis.

Reye's syndrome is a secondary mitochondrial hepatopathy. It is precipitated due to

  • Viral infection (influenza, adenovirus, herpes, coxsackievirus A, Epstein–Barr virus)
  • Salicylate or antiemetic use
  • Inborn error of metabolism such as single enzyme defects of ß oxidation.
  • Toxins

There is an acute onset of vomiting and encephalopathy, rapidly progressing to seizures, coma, and death. There is no jaundice.

Investigations

  • ↑ ALT and AST
  • ↑ Ammonia
  • normal bilirubin
  • Hypoglycemia
  • PT prolonged
  • INR increased
  • Liver biopsy: marked microvesicular steatosis. Necrosis is not seen.

questions.text: A 12-year old girl was rushed to the ER by her parents due to hematemesis. They gave a history of weakness and fatigue for the last few weeks. On examination, the patient had spider telangiectasias and mild palmar erythema. Liver function tests showed the following results- AST-1100IU/L, serum bilirubin- 8mg/dl, albumin- decreased, globulin- elevated, PT- prolonged along with Anti-Nuclear Antibody positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of liver failure and portal hypertension along with a positive anti-nuclear antibody(ANA) is suggestive of Type 1 autoimmune hepatitis. It is associated with- 

  • Elevated serum aminotransaminase concentrations.
  • Liver-associated serum autoantibodies.
  • Hypergammaglobulinemia.

questions.text: A 2-week-old low-birth-weight neonate presents with jaundice. Stools are pale/clay coloured. Liver biopsy shows loss of architecture. The most likely diagnosis is_______.
questions.solution:
Neonatal jaundice in a low-birth-weight (LBW) neonate with consistently pale/clay coloured stools with liver biopsy finding of loss of architecture is suggestive of neonatal hepatitis.

Wilson disease and hereditary hemochromatosis will not present with jaundice in the neonatal stage. Hence, they can be excluded. Injury to liver cells can present the clinical and histologic picture of “neonatal hepatitis.”

Differentiation between Neonatal hepatitis and EHBA

Definition

It implies intrahepatic cholestasis which includes

  • Hepatic injury due to metabolic, viral, or idiopathic causes
  • Intrahepatic bile duct injury
  • Obliteration of the entire extrahepatic biliary tree at or above the porta hepatis(85% cases) OR
  • distal segmental bile duct obliteration with patent
    extrahepatic ducts up to the porta hepatis(uncommon)

questions.text: A mother is concerned about her 3-week-old baby having yellowish discolouration of skin and eyes. On examination, the baby is chubby and playful. Stools are pale in color. Further evaluation with USG shows triangular cord sign and liver biopsy shows bile duct proliferation. The most likely diagnosis is ______.
questions.solution:
Neonatal jaundice in a neonate without a sick-looking appearance and with acholic stools, USG showing triangular cord sign, and liver biopsy showing bile duct proliferation is suggestive of biliary obstruction, which may be seen in biliary atresia.

Wilson disease and Hallervorden Spatz disease (neurodegeneration with iron accumulation in the brain) do not present with jaundice in the neonatal stage. Hence, they can be excluded.

Differentiation between neonatal hepatitis and EHBA

Neonatal hepatitis  Extrahepatic biliary atresia (EHBA) 

It implies intrahepatic cholestasis which includes:

Hepatic injury due to metabolic, viral, or idiopathic cause

Intrahepatic bile duct injury

Distal segmental bile duct obliteration with patent
extrahepatic ducts up to the porta hepatis (uncommon)

Family history is present

Family history absent

Persistent acholic stools

Liver biopsy: Loss of liver architecture

Liver biospy:

  • Biliary atresia is characterized by proliferation of the bile ductule, presence of bile plugs, and portal or perilobular edema and fibrosis, with the basic hepatic lobular architecture intact.
  • In neonatal hepatitis, there is severe, diffuse hepatocellular disease, with distortion of lobular architecture, marked infiltration of inflammatory cells, and focal hepatocellular necrosis.

questions.text: A mother leaves her 3-year-old son unattended for 20 mins and later finds him holding a blue coloured empty strip of tablets with a few tablets scattered on the floor. A few hours later he is rushed to the ER with nausea and vomiting.  As an intern taking the history, you suspect accidental ingestion of paracetamol tablets. The pattern of liver injury you would expect in this case is
questions.solution:
The pattern of liver injury caused by paracetamol (acetaminophen) is centrilobular necrosis.

Acetaminophen toxicity results from the formation of a highly reactive intermediate metabolite, N -acetyl-p -benzoquinone imine (NAPQI). In therapeutic use, only about 5% is metabolized by the hepatic cytochrome P450 enzyme CYP2E1 to NAPQI, which is then immediately joined with glutathione to form a nontoxic mercapturic acid conjugate.

In overdose, glutathione stores are overwhelmed, and free NAPQI is able to combine with hepatic macromolecules to produce hepatocellular necrosis. Single acute toxic dose of APAP is generally considered to be >200 mg/kg in children.

questions.text:
You are examining a young child who presented to the ER with a high fever and abdominal pain. The patient winces on abdominal palpation of the right upper quadrant. USG showed hydrops of the gallbladder. All of the following conditions are associated with hydrops of the gallbladder except
__________.
questions.solution:
Hydrops of the gallbladder is not associated with cystic fibrosis.

Hydrops of gallbladder is the acute acalculous non-inflammatory distension of the gallbladder, which occurs in infants and children. It is characterized by the absence of calculi, bacterial infections or congenital anomalies of the biliary system.

Hydrops is distinguished from acalculous cholecystitis by the absence of a significant inflammatory process and a generally benign prognosis.

Conditions associated with hydrops of GB:

  • Infections: Streptococcal pharyngitis, staphylococcal infection, ascariasis, leptospirosis, typhoid fever, and viral hepatitis
  • Kawasaki disease
  • Total parenteral nutrition, prolonged fasting
  • Sickle cell crisis, thalassemia
  • Sepsis
  • Mesenteric adenitis, necrotizing enterocolitis

Note: In cystic fibrosis cholelithiasis, cholecystitis, micro gallbladder is seen.

questions.text: The commonest indication for liver transplantation in children is ______
questions.solution:
Biliary atresia is the most common indication for liver transplantation in children.

Extrahepatic biliary atresia (EHBA) is defined as a partial or total absence of permeable bile duct between the porta hepatis and the duodenum. It is due to inflammatory fibrosis of the biliary tree. It leads to obstruction to bile flow thereby causing the leaking of conjugated bilirubin into the circulation.

Infants have symptoms of jaundice, pale stools, and dark urine right after birth. In advanced disease, infants present with failure to thrive, hepatomegaly, and ascites due to liver cirrhosis.

HIDA scan is the investigation of choice for extrahepatic biliary atresia. An intraoperative cholangiogram is a gold standard investigation for diagnosis.

Management of extrahepatic biliary atresia
Type I

Atresia restricted to the common bile duct

Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy
Type II

Atresia of the common hepatic duct

 Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy)
Type III

Atresia of the right and left hepatic duct

Children with biliary atresia, who do not achieve successful drainage after hepatoportoenterostomy (Kasai's procedure), require liver transplantation within the first year of life.

questions.text: A young boy was admitted with complaints of fever and abdominal pain for 2 days. ESR and CRP were elevated and CT Abdomen obtained was as shown in the picture. Which of the following is not a common feature in the given condition?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of fever and abdominal pain and a hypodense lesion on the CT are suggestive of a Liver abscess in this patient. 

Signs and symptoms of a liver abscess include fever, chills, night sweats, malaise, nausea, hepatomegaly, as well as pain and tenderness in the right upper quadrant. They also show elevated inflammatory markers, hypoalbuminemia and leukocytosis. However, jaundice is uncommon.
